description: From Middle English ars, ers, from Old English ærs, ears, from Proto-West Germanic *ars, from Proto-Germanic *arsaz (compare Dutch aars and German Arsch), from Proto-Indo-European *h₃érsos (“backside, buttocks”) (according to Julius Pokorny and Carl Darling Buck).

entries.meaning: (Commonwealth, now vulgar) The buttocks or more specifically, the anus.
(chiefly UK, Ireland, Australia, New Zealand, South Africa, derogatory, slang) A stupid, pompous, arrogant, mean or despicable person.
examples: “You're an arse,” Ellen said. ¶ “Please? You must like something about me …?” ¶ “I do. You're an arse. I just told you that. I feel comfy with you, because you're such an arse.”

entries.meaning: (vulgar, slang, uncountable) Used in similes to express something bad or unpleasant.

(vulgar, slang, metonymically, countable) A person; the self; (reflexively) oneself or one's person, chiefly their body; (by extension) one's personal safety, or figuratively one's job, prospects, etc.

verbs.description: arse (third-person singular simple present arses, present participle arsing, simple past and past participle arsed)

entries.meaning: (Commonwealth, slang, intransitive) To be silly, act stupid or mess around.
